title: Inside Tom Cruise’s Brief (but Intense) First Marriage, to Mimi Rogers
article_text: Tom Cruise,star ofMission Impossible: The Final Reckoning,is about to celebrate a whopping 45 years in Hollywood. Over the years, his off-screen life has captured nearly as much attention as his onscreen performances—particularly his marriage toNicole Kidman,which began in 1990 and ended 11 years later. Before then, though, Cruise had relationships with several other actresses and artists—includingCher.In 2018, the Oscar winner dished about their fling in theDaily Mail.She and Cruise bonded, Cher said, in 1985, at a White House event organized by Nancy Reagan. “The White House invited a group of dyslexic people to an event to talk about this learning disorder that, oddly enough, both Tom and I suffer from,” explained the singer and actor, who is 15 years older than Cruise. “Of course, nothing happened there. In fact, we didn’t start dating until later. But the connection between us started that particular night.” When they were both teenagers, Tom Cruise had abrief relationshipwith fellow actorMelissa Gilbert. He reportedly datedRebecca De Mornay,his costar in 1983’sRisky Business: “It’s no secret that Tom engaged in an intense affair during the shooting with De Mornay,” their costarCurtis Armstrongwrote in his memoir.He also datedsingerPatti Scialfabefore she marriedBruce Springsteen. But the woman who most shaped Tom Cruise in this era was actressMimi Rogers,who is six years his senior. Rogers’s father, civil engineer Philip C. Spickler, was a very prominent member of the Church of Scientology, andvery closeto its founder, L. Ron Hubbard. At the time, Rogers was also a Scientologist. (She has sinceleft the church.) According toreporterKim Masters,Rogers was the one who introduced Cruise to Scientology. It took her a while to get into acting. Initially, Rogers was a social worker; she did not move to Los Angeles until she divorced her first husband,Jim Rogers,in 1980. After her move, she shared an apartment with fellow Scientologist Kirstie Alley and began her career as a performer on television, in episodes of series of the time likeHill Street BluesandMagnum, P. I. When she met Cruise in 1985, he was already a superstar—he was preparing to filmTop Gun—and she was still waiting for her big break. (Her first starring film role didn’t come until 1987, when she headlinedRidley Scott’sSomeone to Watch Over Me.) A year later, Cruise confirmed ina cover interview forRolling Stonethat he was with Rogers, whom he had met at a party and found to be an “extremely brilliant” woman. At the time, he was 23, and she was 29. In 1987, they became husband and wife at an intimate ceremony in upstate New York, with a few witnesses as guests—including Cruise’s close friendEmilio Estevez,whose engagement toDemi Moorehad recently ended. The marriage had a positive influence on both of them. “I have a lot of happiness and security. I recommend it [getting married],” Rogers told theChicago Tribunein 1988. Cruise, for his part, toldRolling Stonein January 1990 that being married helped him “become a better actor. We live a lot of things together, we share everything... My wife is the most important thing in the world to me. She’s my best friend. I love being with her. I love her.” But a few days after these words were published, the couple announced through a joint statement that they were separating. “While there have been very positive aspects to our marriage, there were some issues which could not be resolved even after working on them for a period of time,”they said. “Anyone who has been through this type of situation will understand that it is a complicated and difficult decision.” The world later learned Tom had initiated the divorce shortly before he began filmingDays of Thunder.There, he quickly fell in love with Nicole Kidman. “Instant lust, that’s what I felt,” CruisetoldVFin 1995.“I thought she was amazingly sexy and stunning. It grew into love and respect.” In 1993, Rogers posed nude for an issue ofPlayboyand gave an interview in which she opened up about her marriage to Cruise. “Tom was seriously thinking of becoming a monk,” she said. “At least for that period of time, it looked as though marriage wouldn’t fit into his overall spiritual need. And he thought he had to be celibate to maintain the purity of his instrument.” She laterretractedthese comments. In another interview withThe Telegraphin 2001, Rogers spoke again about Cruise, saying that, while his enormous fame did not hurt their marriage, she did feel frustrated with the press always bringing up the age difference between them. “The age thing really got on my nerves,” she said. “Every six months, they’d add another year. If we were still together now, I’d get 60.” In April 1990, Rogers also moved on from her marriage to Cruise: She met producerChris Ciaffa,with whom she has two children—Lucy Rogers-CiaffaandCharles Ciaffa—and whom she married in 2003 in Beverly Hills. She, too, has continued acting, mostly on television in series includingX-Files, Mad Men, Two and a Half Men,and, most recently, as a series regular onBosch.Rogers is also an accomplished poker player: She has played in several professional tournaments, and even served on the board of the World Poker Tour. Cruise, meanwhile, married Kidman,divorced her in 2001,and then entered a relationship withKatie Holmes—but that’s another story. Original story inVF Spain.

title: King Charles Sends Joe Biden a Personal Letter Following His Cancer Diagnosis
article_text: King Charles IIIshowed his support forJoe Bidenin his fightagainst prostate cancer. Buckingham Palace has confirmed that the sovereign, who himself has been undergoing treatmentsince February 2024 for an unspecified form of cancer, wrote a personal letter to the former US president,following the public announcement of his diagnosison Sunday, May 18. The contents of the missive have been kept confidential, according toPeople. The 82-year-old politician and his family are “reviewing treatment options with doctors” to combat his "aggressive" form of cancer coupled with “bone metastases” his personal office said. The disease “appears to be hormone-sensitive, allowing for effective management,” the statement details. Plenty of political figures have mobilized to send the 46th President their best wishes for a speedy recovery in the days since the news became public. "Joe is a fighter—and I know he will face this challenge with the same strength, resilience and optimism that have always defined his life and leadership," assured Biden's former Vice President,Kamala Harris, onX. “No one has done more than Joe to find innovative treatments for cancer in all its forms,” former PresidentBarack Obamadeclared on X, “and I am certain he will meet this challenge with the determination and grace that characterize him.” Trump also took to hisTruth Socialaccount to wish Biden “a speedy and successful recovery” on behalf of himself and his wifeMelania. Though the next day,Trump was already expressing doubts."It takes a long time to get to stage 9," he said to reporters at a press conference, confusing the diagnosis—Biden's cancer is stage 4 with a Gleason score of 9, an index corresponding to the degree of aggressiveness. “There are things going on that the public hasn't been told about, and I think someone's going to have to talk to their doctor,” Trump said. Trump hasn't shied away fromutilizing Biden's perceived healthfor his own political efforts: backed by supporters he was among those toclaim Biden's declining mental acuityas acampaign argument during his run, deeming the former Presidentdangerous for considering a second termin the White House. Biden did not respond to Trump's statement, instead thanking his supporters for their “love and support.” "Cancer touches us all," he wrote on his X (formerly Twitter) account, along with a photo with his wife,Jilland their cat Willow. "Like many of you, Jill and I have learned that it's in the broken places that we are strongest." This content can also be viewed on the site itoriginatesfrom. title: Alexander Skarsgård Wears Thigh-High Boots On the Cannes Film Festival 2025 Red Carpet
article_text: Alexander Skarsgårddidn't just walk up the steps at theCannes Film Festival on Sunday evening. He stomped them, in Saint Laurent thigh-highs no less, for thepremiere ofThe Phoenician Scheme,directorWes Anderson's new film. Under the flashing lights of photographers, the streamlined yet subversive silhouette—a double-breasted jacket with satin lapels and prominent shoulders, a black tie and, above, or below, all, leather thigh-high boots—was inspired by fetishwear. The same leggy footwearcaused a stir at the fashion house's last Fall 2025 show, and was recentlyseen onPedro Pascallast month. Though the majority of men invited to the festival stick to a timeless bow-tie tuxedo, the actor refused to submit to expectations. Halfway between the rigor of Yves Saint Laurent and the aesthetics of Robert Mapplethorpe (the '80s photographer known for his provocative black-and-white work and a major inspiration for creative directorAnthony Vaccarello's Fall show), the look was conceived by stylistHarry Lambert. The ensemble attempts to kickthe established codes of the red carpetmaking it not just a fashion moment, but a demonstration of style as an extension of Skarsgård's on-screen persona. Saint Laurent thigh-high boots from the Fall 2025 collection worn by Alexander Skarsgard on the Cannes Film Festival catwalk. InPillion, directed byHarry Lightonand presented in the festival's Un Certain Regard selection, the Swedish actor plays Ray, the leader of a queer biker gang. He initiates a reserved young man, played byHarry Melling, ofHarry PotterandThe Lady's Gamefame, to an extreme BDSM relationship. Adapted from the novelBox HillbyAdam Mars-Jones, the film explores the power dynamics within a marginalized fetish community. For the screening, the aesthetic tone was already set with Skarsgård's wardrobe choice. Black leather pants, a vintage T-shirt showing a boot crushing a man's face, all complimented by a pair of Loewe motorcycle boots—a silhouette straight out of a '90s cruising bar, and tailored to emulate the sultry protagonist ofPillion(which earned a seven-minute standing ovation). Alexander Skarsgard poses during the photocall forPillionat the 78th Cannes Film Festival at the Palais des Festivals on May 18, 2025 in Cannes, France. While method acting is nothing at Cannes, theBig Little Liesactor seems to be on board with the method dressing trend. This approach turns film promotion into a stylistic performance in its own right. RecallAriana GrandeandCynthia ErivoforWicked;Zendaya's tennis ensembles on theChallengerspress tour;Margot Robbieas a life-size Barbieand now Skarsgård, in turn, embodying a leather dom onscreen and on the carpet. title: Lady Gabriella Windsor On Kate Middleton's “Very Thoughtful” Gesture After Her Husband's Death
article_text: Lady Gabriella Windsorhas given a rare interview, revealing howKate Middletoninvited her to work on her carol concert followingthe death of her husband, Thomas Kingston. The daughter ofPrinceandPrincess Michael of Kent, Lady Windsor, also known as Ella, is the second cousin ofKing Charles III. Shemarried Kingston in 2019at St George’s Chapel in Windsor with the royal family in attendance, including the late Queen Elizabeth II, and wrote and performed a song for her own wedding reception. Tragedy struck the royal family in February of last year, whenKingston was found at his parents' home in the Cotswoldswith a gunshot wound to the head. He had suffered adverse side-effects from prescribed anti-depressants and following an investigation into his death in December, was found that he'd taken his own life. Kate Middleton is said to have asked Lady Gabriella to be involved during the summer last year, in the months following her husband's death Lady Gabriella and her late husband Thomas Kingston Windsor has now spoken of how months later, Middleton invited her to take on an advisory role when it came to her carol concert,Together at Christmas. According toHello!,Windsor was asked to tasked with suggesting music for the service, as well as “putting forward artists and ideas.” Speaking to the publication, she revealed, “It was such an honor to be involved, and very thoughtful and kind-hearted of the Princess to include me. I was very touched.” She went on to say how much she had enjoyed working with the Middleton, adding, “She was so lovely to work with, always gracious, very creative and with so much vision and passion for the many charities and causes she supports." Lady Helen Taylor and Lady Gabriella Windsor arrive for the Together At Christmas carol service at Westminster Abbey on December 6, 2024 Both Windsor and Middleton are around the same age, and both have endured a challenging year apiece in their own rights. Middleton,who was diagnosed with cancer in early 2024, said in a video introduction to the televised service: “This carol service is a heartfelt celebration of every one of you, and a reminder that at Christmas, and throughout the year, we must all shine for each other. Because in times of joy and sadness, we are all each other’s light.” She continued stating, “The Christmas story encourages us to consider the experiences and feelings of others. It also reflects our own vulnerabilities and reminds us of the importance of giving and receiving empathy, as well as just how much we need each other in spite of our differences. Above all else, it encourages us to turn to love, not fear. “The love that we show ourselves and the love we show others. Love that listens with empathy, love that is kind and understanding, love that is forgiving, and love that brings joy and hope. It is love which is the greatest gift we can receive, not just at Christmas but every day of our lives.” Prince William, Prince of Wales, Prince George of Wales, Princess Charlotte of Wales, Prince Louis of Wales and Catherine, Princess of Wales attend the Together At Christmas Carol Service Meanwhile, Lady Windsor's loss of her husband last year heightened the importance of her inclusion in the programing. At an inquest into his death, a statement by Windsor was read aloud byKaty Skerrett, senior coroner for Gloucestershire. “If anything had been troubling him, I’m positive that he would have shared that he was struggling severely. The fact that he took his life at the home of his beloved parents suggests the decision was the result of a sudden impulse,” the statement said. In her statement, Windsor described their marriage as “deeply loving and trusting” and said that her husband had never expressed any suicidal thoughts to her or others. “I believe anyone taking pills such as these need to be made more aware of the side effects to prevent any future deaths. If this could happen to Tom, this could happen to anyone,” the statement continued. Originally published in Vanity Fair Spain Mariska Hargitay Was “Living a Lie” for 30 Years. title: Paul Mescal and Josh O’Connor Tell a Heartbreaking Love Story in ‘The History of Sound’
article_text: How much stifled yearning can one gay period drama take? That’s a question confronted byOliver Hermanus’snew filmThe History of Sound, which premiered here in Cannes on May 21. The film, based on a short story byBen Shattuck, is about two young men who first meet in 1917, just before America heads to war. Those were certainly repressive times for queer people—yet music conservatory students Lionel (Paul Mescal) and David (Josh O’Connor) fall into bed together rather easily, bonding over their shared love of American folk music and no doubt drawn to each other’s considerable good looks. Hermanus doesn’t show us anything particularly steamy, but he does successfully create an air of quiet ardency, especially coming from Lionel. David, the orphan of a wealthy Newport family, is a bit more coy in his affections, while Lionel—who grew up in rural Kentucky before a singing scholarship brought him to study in Boston—looks at David with bedazzled wonderment. But Lionel is a quiet fellow, and the wealth of affection he feels for his friend and lover is never spoken aloud. Soon, the two are separated by war. When a haunted David returns from the trenches, he invites Lionel on a trip around rural Maine, where they will spend their days recording local singers and their nights rolling around together in a tent. The tent stuff does, inevitably, bring to mindBrokeback Mountain, anotherrestrained, handsomely staged dramaof gay men in harsh times. ButHistory of Soundsis on an even lower simmer than that film, asking its audience to sustain themselves mostly on loaded looks and hushed subtext. At times, Hermanus’s style is effective, selling us on the film’s lonely, years-spanning heartsickness. But too often the film’s muted emotion feels more gimmicky than credible to Lionel and David’s circumstances, particularly because Hermanus is so demure about sex; we barely even see the men kissing. Maybe Hermanus is harkening back to a storytelling era when homoeroticism did have to exist as mere suggestion, butHistory of Soundplays more as overly mannered pastiche than worthy contributor to that tradition. Which isn’t to say that the film is without power. As it glides toward its bittersweet conclusion, andChris Cooperenters the picture as an elderly Lionel, the movie’s air of impossible ache becomes potent. It successfully connects romance and music, arguing that Lionel and David’s love was its own kind of eternal folk song—that the small clamor and motion of all of our lives is part of some grander human symphony. Throughout the film, Mescal sturdily embodies Lionel’s restlessness and longing, convincingly portraying a dedicated loner who will never quite stop mourning a life that war, repression, and time denied him. His Kentucky twang may be a bit strained, but otherwise Mescal is a fine vessel for the film’s mood—though I do think I’d like to see him play something other than a laconic tender-heart with watery eyes before too long. (Gladiatordoesn’t count.) It’s O’Connor who makes the strongest impression. Though he has the smaller role, he does a lot with less. He pitches David as wistful, witty, and slightly effete, a child of tragic privilege who may have become some gregarious dandy had his time in France not shell-shocked him so violently. O’Connor makes Lionel’s love for David wholly understandable: who wouldn’t fall for this alluring spirit, with his wry smile that hints at a sad, secret knowledge of the world? O’Connor is so good in the film that, much like Lionel, one hungers for ever more of him. And one pines for the rare drama of this kind which recognizes that, despite the prejudices of the past, there have been gay people in almost every era who enjoyed lasting, wholly requited relationships. Yes, many have been barred—or have barred themselves—from realizing their desire over the centuries. But others did find a way. I would love to see O’Connor in an adaptation of, say,Alan Hollinghurst’sThe Sparsholt Affair, which breathtakingly chronicles a lineage of gay men across the latter half of the 20th century and the beginning of the 21st. Hollinghurst acknowledges what constrained these men while allowing the reader to marvel at the ways they thrived anyway—loved, lost, communed. Of course, stories likeThe History of Soundhave their place too. Hermanus’s film is respectable and frequently poignant. That I wanted to yell at the screen “just tell him you love him and kiss already!” may be owed more to my modern impatience than to any failure of the film. And perhapsHistory of Sounddoes actually have some relevance to today. After all, some of us will never be with Josh O’Connor even when we so desperately want to be. We’re all a little star-crossed, I suppose. This story is part ofAwards Insider’s in-depthCannes coverage, including first looks and exclusive interviews with some of the event’s biggest names. Stay tuned for more Cannes stories as well as a special full week ofLittle Gold Menpodcast episodes, recorded live from the festival and publishing every day. title: What Is Really Going On With Justin and Hailey Bieber?
article_text: Few people were more surprised to seeHailey Bieber’snewVoguecoverthanher husbandJustin,who commemorated the milestone by revealing that he apparently didn’t believe Hailey had this in her. In a May 20Instagrampost sharing the cover imagery, Justin wrote that he once told Hailey during “a huge fight” that she would “never be on the cover ofVogue.” Evidently, he knew this was harsh: “Yikes, I know, so mean,” he added. But the 31-year-old musician concluded his strange remarks by apologizing to his wife, writing, “So baby u already know but forgive me for saying u wouldn’t get a vogue cover cuz clearly i was sadly mistaken.” Bieber’s unprompted admission of doubt raised so many eyebrows that he laterdeletedthe caption, replacing it with a series of emojis reading, “🤷🫵🏻🫶🏼🥹.” In theVoguearticle itself, Bieber praised his wife, writing to the outlet via email, “I’ve done a lot of dumb things in my life, but the smartest thing I’ve ever done was marry Hailey.” Hailey, meanwhile, told the magazine that she follows Justin’s advice when it comes to dealing with the spotlight. “I’ve learned so much from Justin, really,” she said. “He’s been doing this literally since he was a child and he has had to face the most scrutiny of any person that I know. He was, like, ‘Baby, trust me, I’ve been here before many, many times. You’re not going to win. There is no winning.’” The coupletied the knotwith a civil ceremony in 2018, then threw a star-studded2019 weddingin South Carolina. On August 23, 2024, the pairannounced the birth of their son,Jack Blues. Speaking withVogue, Hailey also shared the difficulties of postpartum life, as well as her “scary” labor experience. “Being postpartum is the most sensitive time I’ve ever gone through in my life, and learning a new version of myself is very difficult,” she told the publication. “And to be doing that all the while going on the internet every day and people being, like, ‘They’re getting divorced,’ and ‘They’re this,’ and ‘They’re not happy’—it is such a mindfuck.” As speculation about the state of their marriage ramped up on Wednesday, a source close to the couple spoke out toUs Weekly—telling the tabloid that Hailey “is the most supportive wife” to Justin, who “feels grateful to have her.” The source continued, “They have been through a lot, but have been in a good place these last few months.” That same insider also addressed Justin’s recent trips to Finland and Iceland, telling the outlet, “Justin needed a change of pace in order to feel inspired creatively again. Justin has had dark days recently and is going through a lot of changes in his life.” A second source described this time in Justin’s life as a “self-reflection and healing period.” In recent months, Bieber’sseemingly erratic behaviorandvulnerable postson social media have fueled rumors about his home life with Hailey. At the start of the year, he unfollowed Hailey on Instagram, thenrefollowed herthat same morning, writing on his Instagram story, “Someone went on my account and unfollowed my wife.” On March 30, it was Hailey’s turn to unfollow her husband for about two days. But in a TikTok comment, she claimed that this too was an accident: “It’s a glitch,” she wrote, as reported byPage Six.“Didn’t unfollow him. Hope this helps!” Last month, fans expressed concern over a video of Justin partying at Coachella and posting photos of himself with a bong. “Justin is having fun, vibing out and, yes, he smokes weed like everyone else,” a source toldPeople.“But everything he does is being weaponized against him.” That same source refuted any divorce rumors. “Hailey is not on the verge of wanting a divorce or leaving him. It’s just completely untrue,” the source said. “If anything, she’s sad about how hard everyone is being on him now that he finally is coming back out of his shell.” A second source close to Justin reiterated this sentiment toPeople. “Hailey’s very loyal to him. She’s not walking away, but she knows something has to change,” said the source. “Her focus is raising [their son] Jack in a stable environment. She’s drawn a line around what she’s willing to tolerate. She means the world to Justin. They have quietly weathered more than most couples ever do.” That same month, one of Justin’s former team members toldThe Hollywood Reporterthat the singer was “lost” with “no one protecting him,” alleging that he was also millions of dollars in debt aftercancelinghisJusticetour in 2022. A rep for Justin lambasted theTHRreport. “This is just clickbait stupidity based on unnamed—and clearly ill-informed —‘sources,’ disappointed that they no longer work with Justin,” the rep toldPeoplein April. “As Justin forges his own way forward, these unnecessary stories and inaccurate assumptions will continue. But, they won’t deter him from staying committed to following the right path.” The couple was last spotted in public together at a hockey game on May 18, where they cuddled while watching the Toronto Maple Leafs play the Florida Panthers.Vanity Fairhas reached out to reps for both Hailey and Justin for comment. title: Dior Spas Are Redesigning Wellness
article_text: For more than a century, theHôtel Plaza Athénéein Paris, located at 25 Avenue Montaigne, has offered its guests a luxurious respite amid the bustling city streets and the chance to indulge in l’art de vivre, the art of living well. Just a few doors down, at 30 Avenue Montaigne, fashiondesigner Christian Diordid the same when establishing his couture house in 1946. It was there that he would eventually create the iconic Bar suit, his new look, a style he dreamed up for the women who dined at Le Relais Plaza, the hotel’s Michelin-starred restaurant. Many of its star-studded clientele—Marlene Dietrich,Rita Hayworth,Ava Gardner,Lauren Bacall,Jackie Kennedy,Elizabeth Taylor, andSophia Lorenamong them—morphed from muses to devotees, often making their way across the avenue to shop at Dior. In 2008 the hotel and the fashion house made the relationship official with the completion of the Dior Spa Plaza Athénée. Today, the synergy has been renewed with a fresh renovation of the tranquil space well-known for its high-tech treatments accented by sumptuous details characteristic of the French fashion house. Here, warm lighting sets a gentle mood as a marble pool engraved with the brand’s signature rose des vents invites guests to explore a range of sophisticated treatments from light therapy to massage to facials to cryotherapy. Five single-occupancy treatment rooms are reflective of significant themes in Dior’s life— Constellation, for his love of astrology; Miss Dior, for the first fragrance made in honor of his sister Catherine; Montaigne, for the Plaza Athénée and Dior studios; Granville, for the designer’s birthplace; New Look, for his 1947 collection launch—and one additional room is dedicated solely to light therapy. Dior Prestige La Micro-Huile de Rose Activated Serum Dior Dior Prestige La Crème Texture Essentielle Dior Inside the Dior Light Suite, created in partnership with the innovative French lighting company Lucibel·le Paris, an LED-studded ceiling mimics the incandescence of the sun, delivering a doctor-approved dose of sunlight to help rebalance energy levels, encourage healthy sleep, and erase signs of fatigue. The “sky” diffuses a natural light, with three levels of intensity: energizing, relaxing, and regenerating. For those plagued by jet lag or those struggling with daily stressors, three new 105-minute treatments inspired by the sun claim to aid in resetting circadian and chronobiological rhythms, each coupling light therapy with a complementary massage. “Recover” cloaks the body in amber-hued half-light during a stimulating massage. “Rest” offers a mix of sensorial stimulation through light that channels the sunset and massage. This weary traveler opted for the D-Tissue massage to release tension and reoxygenate muscles, essentially reharmonizing one’s internal clock for restoration and rejuvenation. Elsewhere, this month, Dior is continuing its commitment to wellness with a new location at theSplendido, a Belmond Hotel,in Portofino. Set between the gardens and the ocean, Spa Splendido is the first permanent Dior spa in Italy, with a focus on well-being. The signature service there, Splendidior, is a holistic treatment for both face and body, promising to offer full relaxation, with guided energizing power utilizing semiprecious stones. Ready for a new look and feel, sign me up, pronto. Mariska Hargitay Was “Living a Lie” for 30 Years. title: The Elon Musk Rebrand Is in Full Swing. But Will Anyone Buy It?
article_text: Gone was the black MAGA hat. So too, thechainsaw. LittleX AE A-12? Perched presumably somewhere other than his father’s shoulders in the Oval Office. Instead, asElon Musksat down for an interviewTuesday inside Tesla’s gigafactory, a sleek fleet of electric vehicles parked just behind him, he seemed determined to send a clear message: That he was getting back to the serious business of being a CEO. Well, serious except for the fact that he was wearing a Tesla-branded jacket with the word “S3XY” embroidered on it. This is still the same guy who loves apot jokeandpoop emoji, after all. The CNBC interview appeared tailor-made to facilitate Musk’s reentry to the corporate world, as he eases his way out of hismuch reviled government roleat the Department of Government Efficiency. The post-DOGE media tour also included a stop at the Qatar Economic Forum, whereMusk declaredthat his days ofdoling out hundreds of millions of dollarsto Republicans may be over. “In terms of political spending, I’m going to do a lot less in the future,” Musk said at the forum. “I think I’ve done enough.”Asked whether this change has anything to do with the blowback his businesses have faced, Musk dodged the question saying simply, that he doesn’t “currently see a reason” to continue pouring money into politics. It was a remarkable admission for a man who warned last year that “the fate of western civilization” was at stake in the 2024 election and who said that the country was teetering onthe edge of bankruptcywhenPresident Trumptook office. Yet now—as DOGE’s cost-cutting efforts continue tofall far short of the $2 trillionin cuts Musk promised, and as the president pushes House Republicans to pass a spending package that wouldincrease the deficit by nearly $4 trillion—Musk suddenly believes his work here is done? The truth is, regardless of what Musk does in the future, it’s clearly in his best interest—and the best interest of his businesses—to look like he’s bowing out of politics. Musk’s unparalleled support for the Trump campaign and intensely public work for the administration have torpedoed his companies’ reputations. According toa new Harris poll, which measured the reputation of the 100 most visible brands in America, both X and Tesla ranked in the bottom 10. When it comes to corporate “character,” Tesla was last. In 2021, before Musk took over Twitter,Tesla scoredthe 8th best reputation in the same poll, according to Axios. SpaceX scored equally poorly this year, ranking in the bottom 10 companies for “character,” “trust,” and “citizenship.” This reputational damage has had a huge financial impact, withTesla’s first quarter profits dropping71% since the same time last year. Musk, of course, is loathe to admit the connection. He insisted during the Qatar forum that while Tesla has “lost some sales, perhaps on the left, we've gained them on the right.” He also said that Tesla’s prospects have “already turned around,” citing the recent uptick in the company’s stock price. But that uptick is inextricably tied to Musk’s public announcement that he would soon be spending less time at DOGE and his marked shift away from posting about politics on X over the last two months.One analysis byThe Washington Postthis week found that more than half of Musk’s posts on X were about politics in February, while less than 10% of them mentioned his companies. Now, the balance has flipped. The question now is whether people will actually buy Musk’s attempted rebrand. On one hand, memories can be short, as evidenced by the fact thatDonald Trumpwon a second term in office, after being effectively run out of Washington after the January 6 insurrection. On the other, political moneymen tend to have a hard time shaking that reputation. Just look atGeorge Soros, a wildly successful businessman, who, at least on the right, will never be regarded as anything other than a left-wing boogeyman. Musk is no Soros. He's something more. In a short mount of time, the role he has played in American politics is singular. Combining the force of his unrivaled wealth, his global fame, his online platform, and his virtually unfettered (thoughpotentially unlawful) authority to reshape government agencies, he has gleefully wielded unprecedented power. And his media tour has not been an apology tour. In both the CNBC interview and his appearance at the Qatar forum, Musk brazenly defended DOGE's work and threatened his critics. Did he regret any of his political endeavors, the interviewer in Qatar asked? Musk thought for a moment, before replying, “I did what needed to be done.” Mariska Hargitay Was “Living a Lie” for 30 Years. title: How TheSkimm, Once Deemed “the Ivanka Trump of Newsletters,” Grew Into a Must-Read for Political Leaders on the Left—and Right
article_text: WhenDanielle WeisbergandCarly Zakinfirst launchedTheSkimm,a daily news-digest email aimed at busy young women, back in2012,media critics dismissed the conversational tone, mix of low and highbrow content, and use of memes. In 2017,Slatedubbed it“theIvanka Trumpof newsletters” that “treats its readers like they’ve never read an article, looked at a map, or accidentally seen a CNN segment in their dentists’ waiting rooms.” How times have changed: With more than 5 million active subscribers across its email products, according toAxios, TheSkimmhas earned its reputation as a crucial media resource for female readers who are interested in the world. AndTheSkimmitself is doing important things for that world. When, by the end of thefirst dayofDonald Trump’s second term, a government-run website with reproductive health information, ReproductiveRights.gov, abruptly vanished,TheSkimmabsorbed the content and republished it.The Skimmplans to host the resurrected page in perpetuity. The move wasn’t about partisanship for Weisberg and Zakin, who, in a wide-ranging interview withVanity Fair,say they have no plans to endorse candidates in the future. The person whose team they’re on hasn’t changed since they launched the business from their shared couch: It’s �“her,” their one-word shorthand for their readership. “What our audience realized, probably even before we realized, is there was no knight in shining armor from the government—no matter what government was in power—that was coming to save her,” Zakin said. “When I say ‘save her,’ I mean give her the support that she needs and the economic policies that she needs to continue to be a contributor to the economy, to be able to have a family so that we don’t have a dwindling population rate. I think it is made very clear to our audience, millions of her across this country who all represent different political arms, that nobody is ever coming to help. And that’s a really bitter pill to swallow.” TheSkimmis still as likely to give Kardashian shenanigans top billing in a newsletter as it is to spotlight the latest in ceasefire talks. Now, though, instead of deliriously refreshing the wires themselves all night before the morning send, Weisberg and Zakin head an operation made up of more than 75 full-time employees, according toAxios.Digital media giant Ziff Davis, which ownsWhat to Expect, Mashable, BabyCenter,and more,recently bought the companyfor an undisclosed amount. (Weisberg and Zakin declined to discuss specifics of the deal.) For this conversation, we sat down at Cafe Cluny in New York City’s West Village, right around the corner from the walk-up they used to share when they launchedTheSkimm. “It’s actually how we got the earliest celebrity fans,” Zakin said of the restaurant that once served as their de facto office, which a friend sent a sketch of as a gift celebrating the acquisition. “Julianne Moorewas there all the time.” The roommates turned cofounders are clearly still close: They still order fries (Weisberg checks that Zakin is getting fries as a side before she opts for greens as her own, then the two align on their dip choices) and nudge each other as multiple celebrities walk in, and they—no joke—finish each other’s sentences several times throughout the conversation. Read on to find out which politicos readTheSkimm,what the algorithm dishes out to Weisberg and Zakin, and how the founders plan to help women be their own heroes. This interview has been edited and condensed for clarity. Vanity Fair:The voice ofTheSkimmhas changed a lot over the years. Can you talk about finding the balance for a conversational tone about serious topics? Carly Zakin:Back when we started, we called it news, but it was zeitgeist. Danielle Weisberg:It was inclusive of the news, but also what was happening in our generation and being talked about. Zakin:Our ethos was like, it doesn’t matter who you are, what your job is, if you are at a work-networking thing, or a wedding, or whatever, and somebody is talking about something happening in the world, you should know what they’re talking about. We never wanted anybody to have a deer-in-headlights moment. The algorithm seems to be everywhere these days. You spend a lot of time together and have a lot of the same interests—are you two on the same internet? Zakin:Danielle and I are on the same internet. Weisberg:Yes. Zakin:Our spouses are not. Weisberg:Definitely not. How would you describe your internet? Weisberg:We were on the way here together sitting next to each other in an Uber. And I texted my sister, who works in art, something from theDaily Mailabout a gallery, and seconds later Carly texted my sister and me the exact same thing. And my sister was like, “Aren’t you guys next to each other?” How would you characterize your readership, and has it changed over the years? Weisberg:We talk about “her” or “she”—that is who we have obsessed over. She’s so educated. She has been told growing up that she could do anything. And then the expectation was, “You can have it all.” But do youwantit all? What does that mean and how do you actually keep that up without losing yourself or your mind? We really saw, especially in the pandemic, was no one’s coming to save her. There’s no secret solution for all of this. What we’ve experienced, and I think what our audience has also shown us, is she’s helping herself. Whether that’s through creating a sense of community, whether it is through looking for practical ways to make your life easier or better. Part of that is information to make those decisions. That’s always what we’ve thought about with who she is, what she’s doing, what she’s going to trust, and how much time is she going to give us. Zakin:When I look back to what this journey has been, there’s the before and after of 2020, and we’ve seen the business through so many different global challenges and industry challenges, and it’s part of why we’re very proud of how we exited, and continuing to meet our audience where she is. Your company explicitly says it’sforwomen. How do you keep that focus without tipping over into gimmick? Weisberg:It’s evolved over time, as it should and as our audience has, and we’ve all grown up. I always think back to some of the earliest criticism that we got, which was, “How is it okay to write about things that are serious in a truncated way? How is it okay to give weight to both what’s going on with the Kardashians and what’s going on in Egypt in the same short amount of space?” People were very serious about this criticism. And this is in the age ofBuzzFeedand listicles and it always felt to me like such a hallmark of this self-importance that I think can be found in coastal media. It’s not at all indicative of how people speak or how they live their lives, which is not in silos: “This is when I’m going to think about politics; this is when I’m going to think about things I’m interested in.” It is all of those things at probably the same time and in the same conversation, when you need to know it. And you probably only have a certain amount of time to actually consume information. Forever, our number one hallmark or touchstone with our voice was, “It needs to be authentic to who she is and what’s on her mind. What are the stressors?” And those two things, while patterns of speech and colloquialisms have changed and should continue to change over time, those two things have always been the most important. Is the reader growing with you? Does she also include a 21-year-old? Your mom’s friend? Weisberg:The best way that I describe who she is, is she’s someone that’sin it. “In it” could mean someone who is watching, or experiencing, or will soon be on the path to taking care of your kids and your parents at the same life stage. Recognizing that thesandwich generationis coming for you or being part of it is something that completely changes the way that you approach so many things. But someone that’s in it could also be someone who just graduated from college and is thinking about how they’re going to support themselves and what that might look like in the future. It’s someone who is just trying to make really good decisions in the midst of a really turbulent time. I want to talk about the Reproductive Rights page that you republished after it was removed from government websites. I know thatTheSkimmis adamantly nonpartisan. What was the thought process behind this move? Weisberg:Just by doing something around reproductive rights, you are labeled as partisan in some way. And how we looked at it is, women’s health is not political. It has beenpoliticized. Access to information around it should be a fundamental, easily accessed right. Zakin:I think also, it’s so funny, I go back to, “Okay, when we started what was the environment?” And we were like, “It was the heyday of cable news. It was the heyday of Twitter.” And it was still called Twitter. Everything felt so partisan [then] and it’s cute that we thought that. I think to where things are today and there is no shortage of finding people’s opinions and even debating what is fact, what is not fact. What we always were intentional about was not to build a brand based out of New York and alike audiences. We live in New York, and started this in New York, and we could never have built what we builtnotbeing in New York, honestly, but our audience has always been spread across the country. Our audience is also, they don’t all look the same way. When you look at how this last election went, overwhelmingly, especially if you look at white women, over 60% supported Trump. The mistake that we’ve seen so many media outlets make is thinking they know how an audience feels. Have you gotten pushback or heard from the current administration on anything? Weisberg:No. But I’ll also say there were oftentimes in previous administrations where we got pushback too. Zakin:Absolutely. Weisberg:Very direct. Can you say more about that? Weisberg:No. Zakin:I will say that leadership on both sides of the aisle are avid Skimmers. Can you tell me about any issues or upcoming focuses on your mind? Zakin:We are obsessed with the fact that this generation is facing, no matter who she is or where she is in life, having dependents on both sides. And especially when you think about taking care of parents and—not even taking care of them, but actually having the tough conversations with them and knowing everything from where their medical records are to is their money saved to get them care? What’s their insurance? All of that. The two of you have been at this together for 13 years and are clearly still so close. Does the enormity of that journey ever just hit you? Weisberg:Celebrating things has been a big part of our journey. The story could have gone in so many different ways. I think about it as someone else’s story, looking back. It is wild that we’ve done it and we’ve done it together and had some really weird times. Mariska Hargitay Was “Living a Lie” for 30 Years. title: Lap of Luxury: Where the Stars Prepare for the Cannes Film Festival 2025
article_text: There's no Cannes Film Festival 2025 without gowns, tuxedos, jewelry and make-up. Or without meticulous preparation, sometimes lasting several hours, before climbing the steps and walking the world's most-watched red carpet. But to complete their transformations, stars can’t go just anywhere. Instead, they make themselves in these discreet but often spectacular locations, scattered along the Croisette. The best view of the Croisette is from the Chopard terrace at Martinez. As an official partner of the Cannes Film Festival, the Swiss jeweler makes a point of setting up here every year to showcase itsart de vivre(and adorn its actresses) in spectacular fashion. Fresh flowers, buffets, deep armchairs, long terraces floating in the sky: it's here, a setting accessible by invitation only, where celebrities come to choose their finery before ascending the steps. The Chopard terrace at the Hotel Martinez in Cannes. Stylists are of course welcome as well, as are a handful of journalists. Chopard's artistic directorCaroline Scheufeleis a regular visitor too. She was responsible for the spectacular pieces worn byJuliette BinocheandBella Hadidat this year’s opening ceremony, as well as those worn byPom KlementieffandHalle Berryat the premiere of the filmMission Impossible — The Final Reckoning. Another favorite address for the stars of the Croisette: the Hotel Le Majestic, located at the foot of the Palais des Festival, where Dior sets up shop every year to brighten up appearances with colorful powders and blushes. Concealer, blush, lipstick, highlighter—here, each face is placed in the hands of the house's top makeup artists, with a choice of sea views or the prestigious red carpet. The Dior suite at the Le Majestic hotel in Cannes. This season, the suite is decorated with objects from the Dioriviera collection in natural materials such as sisal and rattan, which weave together palm trees, elephants, giraffes, and cacti—ideal ingredients for an exotic journey. Anamaria Vartolomei,Kristen Stewart,Nana Komatsu, and more all slipped into the Chanel suite before walking the red carpet, in the hands of the house's top beauty specialists. With iridescent blush, glossy lip gel, luminous eyeshadow, and eyeliner for doe eyes, the label pays particular attention to achieving balanced, contemporary makeup looks. The Chanel suite at the Le Majestic hotel in Cannes. This beauty treatment takes place in one of the suites of the Le Majestic hotel, in a powdery, intimate setting just a stone's throw from the Palais des Festivals. Hairstyling, make-up, manicures: L'Oréal takes care of everything. For 28 years, the group has been at the forefront as the official partner of the Cannes Festival. This year, it celebrates the fifth anniversary of the Lights on Women's Worth award, chaired this season by Oscar-winning actorViola Davis. The competition puts a spotlight on women in cinema, and rewards the winner with financial support of 30,000 euros. Eva Longoria on the balcony of the L'Oréal space at the Martinez in Cannes. But the real star of the space isEva Longoria, the house's loyal muse since 2005. The 50-year-old star is celebrating 20 years of collaboration with the French group. Tom Cruise's sensational arrival at Cannes, the polo shirt everyone's talking about, and, by the way, many of theMission Impossible 8crew's looks? They're all by Orlebar Brown, the superlative men's beachwear label. In the gardens of the Carlton, in a beautiful white space with a half-Hamptons, half-Santa Monica influence, you'll find this relaxed wardrobe adored by stars includingJay Z, Cristiano Ronaldo,andVincent Cassel. The Orlebar Brown boutique, in the gardens of the Carlton, Cannes. Here you'll find everything you need to make the coolest appearances on the Croisette: the silk Horton polo shirt (worn by Cruise), but also exceptional floral prints, available in shorts, swimwear, and shirts. Celebrities visiting the Carlton know they’ll find not only something to wear in the pool that’s literally facing the boutique, but also clothing made of linen, gorgeous terrycloth, and seersucker—perfect for a press conference, a cocktail party, a villa party, and, why not, breakfast under the Croisette sun. Tom Cruise's Orlebar Brown polo shirt, the star of the 78th Cannes Film Festival The coolest independent British designer is in Cannes for the first time this year, in a suite at the Majestic Hotel. Here, you'll meet a host of actors, either in person or in the company of their stylists, who have made some of the most charming appearances at this 78th edition of the Cannes Film Festival. The Paul Smith space at the Majestic, open during the Cannes Festival. The Paul Smith space at the Majestic, open during the Cannes Film Festival. Augustin Dewinter, Edward Norton, Nahuel Pérez Biscayart, Laure Calamy,andHarry Mellingwere just some of those who spent time here, discovering pieces for their festival walk as well as a fine selection of more relaxed looks, perfect for afternoon press conferences or a one-on-one meeting with a producer by the pool. This is one ofJulianne Moore's favorite spots, where she pampers her skin before hitting the red carpet. A one-hour treatment using Carita's "Metamorphic" range relieves tension and targets the meridians—the interconnected channels through which the body's vital energy circulates in traditional Chinese medicine. The Carita spa at the Hôtel Martinez in Cannes. Original story inVF France.

title: Michelle Williams Remembers Heath Ledger: He Was “So Special”
article_text: Many years after the passing of Heath Ledger, who died in 2008 of anaccidental drug overdose, his ex-girlfriendMichelle Williamsopened up about their bond during an episode of theArmchair Expertpodcast, hosted byDax Shepard. Shepard, too, knew Ledger a bit, he told his guest. “I feel obligated to say that I knew him a little bit when he was getting sober,” Shepard said. “And I don’t know that I’ve ever fallen in love with someone so quickly. This is one of the most special boys I’ve ever met. And I can feel the weight of the world on him in a very special way that kind of broke my heart.” Williams replied, in a whisper, that Ledger was “so special,” repeating it a few times. “Thank God there’sMatilda,” she added, referring to her and Ledger’s now 19-year-old daughter. Williams and Ledger met on the set ofBrokeback Mountain, where they played a married couple grappling with an enormous secret: Ledger’s character, Ennis, was hiding his homosexuality, and his relationship withJake Gyllenhaal’s Jack, who in turn was married toAnne Hathaway’sLureen. Matilda Rose Ledger was born during the film’s promotional tour, in October 2005. As Shepard pointed out, everyone inBrokeback’s cast went on to enormous fame and accolades. “How was the life-altering shift of, you’re going to be at the Academy Awards?” he asked Williams “Was that a natural transition?” “No,” replied Williams. “We had a baby. But I suppose maybe it’s a good thing about being young, is that you don’t have so much life experience that you can contextualize things. So you’re really just going with the flow.” Williams and Ledger broke up 12 months before Ledger’s death. Williams raised Matilda on her own for several years. She’s now a parent to three more kids with her husband, directorThomas Kail: Hart,born in 2020; a second child, born in 2022; and a third born in the spring of 2025. As such, Williams has gradually become more confident in her abilities as a mother. “When I make mistakes in front of my daughter, and own up to them and apologize, it teaches her to make mistakes and say, ‘Oopsie, Mommy, I’m sorry.’ And it’s not a big deal,” she told Shepard. “It’s a part of life, and we move on. No shame, no blame. Just, ‘You made a mistake? Beautiful. I made five already today.’” Back in 2016, in aninterviewwithPortermagazine, Williams talked about her experience as a single mother after Ledger’s death. “In all honesty, for pretty much everything else, I feel like I’m a believer in not fighting circumstances, accepting where you are and where you’ve been,” she said then. “In pretty much all senses but one, I would be able to go totally down that line of thinking were it not for Matilda not having her dad. You know, that’s just something that doesn’t…I mean, it just won’t ever be right.” Original story inVFItaly. Mariska Hargitay Was “Living a Lie” for 30 Years. title: Give the Real Housewives an Emmy, You Cowards
article_text: God blessJean Smart, but I don’t know if I can watch her winanother Emmy. She’s already collected three for her delicious work onHacks—she’s never been nominated for the series without winning—and this September she will likely be called to the stage for her fourth. John Oliver’sLast Week Tonight,meanwhile, has won30 awards in 11 years, and I can recite from memory his perennial speech thanking staff members in Brooklyn. Some 140 years ago, when Nietzsche advanced the concept of eternal return, he was talking about how boring the Emmys are. All this is not entirely the voters’ fault—television is built on multiseason series—but they’ll clearly vote for the same people over and over until they get carpal tunnel. The result is that the industry’s most respected awards show has been stagnant and zeitgeist-adjacent a long time. Even as a teen, I remember watchingFrasierwin best comedy series five years in a row and thinking, Is that all there is? The Emmys need more electricity and drama, by which I mean they need reality stars. Yes, the Television Academy rewards reality TV, but mostly at the Creative Arts Emmys a week earlier, which has all the glitz and buzz of Air Force Two. The prime-time Emmys can start reinventing itself by adding two new categories to the broadcast—one for best performance in a reality program and another for best performance in a reality competition. The former would bring stars likeThe Real Housewives of Potomac’s Gizelle Bryant,Salt Lake CityHousewife Mary Cosby, andLove Is Blind’s Hannah Jiles into the drowsy theater. These are not women who are going to give polite speeches thanking their agents. These are women who know how to deliver. They will be a renewable resource of theatrics and priceless sound bites. Reality competition, meanwhile, would recognize contestants from beloved series likeSurvivor,The Traitors,The Bachelor,andRuPaul’s Drag Race.Contestants fromSurvivorcan be weird, funny, savvy, and fiercely intelligent:Mike Whitewas on the show long before he createdThe White Lotusand made brotherly incest a subplot of prestige TV. Reality series have given us charming, ruthless pop-culture icons like Parvati Shallow and Boston Rob, not to mention Gabby Windey, who’s a mixture of Luanne fromKing of the Hilland Elle Woods fromLegally Blonde.Windey was put on this earth to be quoted and memed. I’m suggesting these new categories primarily to bringfunback to the Emmys, but let’s not forget that reality TV helps power every successful network and streamer. Last November, Comcast announced that it would spin off most of its linear cable networks into a separate company while retaining Bravo. If the Television Academy is concerned about the ratings of its awards show, it should let some of the most passionate fandoms into the tent. To treat a whole sector of programming as “less than” is to turn your back on relevance at a time when every pair of eyeballs matters. And if you’re not convinced that a reality TV performance could be worth honoring, direct your own eyeballs to Bob the Drag Queen’s speech at that memorableTraitorsroundtable—it was a wig-snatching Shakespearean tour de force. By the way, reality stars will make for great TV even when they lose because they won’t go quietly into the night. We know this from experience: Donald Trump has whined about losing out on an Emmy forThe Apprenticefor years and called the show “dishonest,” “a con game,” and “sooooo boring.” The first two criticisms are absurd. The third one’s worth thinking about. Mariska Hargitay Was “Living a Lie” for 30 Years. title: Hong Kong private clinics must apply for licence from October, amid rules revamp
article_text: ‘Negative vetting’ process will see licensing regime gazetted on Friday, following earlier moves targeting hospitals and day procedure centres The Health Bureau said on Wednesday that the new rules would be gazetted on Friday. The changes fall under the Private Healthcare Facilities Ordinance, which was passed in 2018 but enacted in phases, starting with hospitals in 2019 and day procedure centres in 2020. A licence will be required to operate a clinic under the ordinance, which stipulates specific requirements for areas such as staffing and equipment. Codes of practice related to clinic operations will also be gazetted on Friday and come into effect on October 13. Clinics that opened on or before November 30, 2018, can apply for a licence between October and April 13 next year.

title: Hong Kong Red Cross tightens female blood donor rules for first time in 30 years
article_text: Haemoglobin threshold increased after number of blood donors rejected fell from nearly 40,000 in 2015 to 10,000 last year The Hong Kong Red Cross has tightened the haemoglobin requirement for female blood donors for the first time in 30 years, as the number who failed to meet the threshold and were turned away dropped nearly 75 per cent in a decade. Dr Lee Cheuk-kwong, chief executive and medical director of the Hong Kong Red Cross Blood Transfusion Service, said on Tuesday that, effective from May 27, the haemoglobin threshold for female blood donors would be raised from a range of 11.5-12 grams per decilitre, to between 12g/dl and 16.5g/dl. The requirement for male donors will remain unchanged. The decision was made after a considerable reduction in the number of blood donors rejected for insufficient haemoglobin, from nearly 40,000 in 2015 to 10,000 last year. “We notice that there is a significant improvement in haemoglobin levels among the regular donor population. Part of that is related to our education and awareness programmes, which have been impactful for more than 10 years,” Lee said. While about 10 out of 70 people are currently rejected every day due to insufficient haemoglobin, Lee estimated that around 10 more would be turned away daily for the same reason under the raised threshold. He also noted that other reasons for rejection included overseas travel, taking prescribed medication, and having the flu.

title: EU hands US state media outlet €5.5 million lifeline
article_text: The European Union has pledged €5.5 million in emergency funding to Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty (RFE/RL) to prop up the Cold War-era broadcaster, which is widely regarded as a Western propaganda outlet. Originally created in the 1950s and covertly financed by the CIA to disseminate pro-Western narratives into the Soviet bloc, RFE/RL has more recently operated under the oversight of the US Agency for Global Media (USAGM). In March, President Donald Trump signed an executive order eliminating most of the agency’s funding as part of a sweeping cost-cutting agenda. EU foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas announced the bloc’s financial lifeline on Tuesday, describing it as“short-term emergency funding”to support what she called a“vital”mission. The €5.5 million package will act as a“safety net”to help RFE/RL maintain operations in countries within Brussels’s sphere of interest, including Russia, Belarus, Iran, and several Central Asian states. “In a time of growing unfiltered content, independent journalism is more important than ever,”Kallas said following a meeting of EU foreign ministers. She acknowledged that Brusssels could not fully replace the lost American funding but emphasized the symbolic value of the move, urging individual member states to offer further support. Since Trump’s defunding order, RFE/RL has furloughed staff, suspended programming, and launched legal challenges. Although a Washington judge temporarily halted the administration’s decision in April, a federal appeals court later blocked the release of funds pending further litigation. The broadcaster has warned that it faces permanent shutdown in multiple regions if its financial crisis is not resolved. The Trump administration framed the defunding as part of a broader campaign to dismantle bureaucratic institutions that no longer align with US strategic interests. RFE/RL’s leadership has disputed that rationale, with its president, Stephen Capus, calling the funding cuts a“massive gift to America’s enemies.” Administration officials and critics have argued that RFE/RL and its sister outlet, Voice of America (VOA), have lost their relevance and veered toward partisan editorializing. Tech billionaire Elon Musk, who heads the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), has publicly called for both outlets to be“shut down,”writing on X:“Nobody listens to them anymore.”
